p: This virus is transmitted among vertebrate hosts, such as marsupials, sloths, primates, and birds, through a generally wild transmission cycle by the Ochlerotatus serratus and Culex quinquefasciatus mosquitoes. Notably, this arbovirus has adjusted to an urban transmission cycle with humans as the main reservoir and Culicoides paraensis (Ceratopogonidae) as the main vector. Thus, there is a worrisome risk of ORO emergence in the densely populated coast of Brazil, which cover the northeastern and southeastern regions, considering that vector C. paraensis is present in low-altitude areas of the entire Brazilian territory [ 7, 10]. Moreover, Cx. quinquefasciatus mosquitoes are spread throughout the Brazilian cities, suggesting the need to pay more attention to this mosquito species too.
